18 is the latest approved patch-set.
No files were changed between the latest approved patch-set and the submitted one.
Few small issues, otherwise lgtm
Spacing
Done
Spacing
Done
Spacing
Done
Perhaps I'm missing something, but would `open(O_RWDR | O_CREAT | O_APPEND)` be a simpler way to achieve pretty much the same thing?

log_create is used to get the fd/size of the log file

It uses stat function to check if log file exists, and if doesn't, create a new one.

if it does, open the file with O_APPEND flag

But what does that manual sequence achieve that a single `open(O_RDWR | O_CREAT | O_APPEND)` wouldn't?

And actually on a separate note, I see the `O_RDWR` is in the existing code and not introduced in this patch, but it's not clear to me why we even need `O_RDWR` instead of `O_WRONLY`...

Prior to `93fd8a39d8d2 ("log_trim: Rotate log instead of truncate")` the algorithm for maintaining the log `mmap()`ed the log file storage to implement a ring-buffer. The referenced patch changed that to the rename approach we now use, which is closer to logrotate. `O_RDWR` is a hangover from the `mmap()` days.

I agree with @zev the implementation should now use `open(..., O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_APPEND)` and save on the complexity proposed here.
Done
This looks better. I found one further issue regarding consistency of `open()` flags.
The open flags need to be the same here as below. Perhaps use a macro or add a flags member to `struct log_handler` so we can't make them inconsistent.

Maybe

open(lh->log_filename, O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_TRUNC, 0644); ？truncate log file（creat a new file） and set the lh->size = 0. 

O_APPEND and set lh->size = 0, looks a bit weird
or Maybe I don't understand your comment :(

I think what Andrew meant was just that we should ensure we always use the same set of flags when we open the log file.  Because there are two places that call `open()` to do that, we need to make sure that both places pass the same flags.  One option for a clean way of achieving that would be to do something like:

```
#define LOGFILE_O_FLAGS (O_WRONLY | O_CREAT | O_TRUNC)
```

and then just pass `LOGFILE_O_FLAGS` to `open()` in both places.
Sorry for taking so long to get back to this, but yes, what Zev said above 😊
Done
Done
Needs some testing, but from a quick look seems okay.
I'm okay with the change, but if you do end up re-submitting for another reason, there's a suggestion inline for a clarification.
Done

Combined with the message below, this reads like you're actually trying to seek the file (ie, change the file position pointer), rather than query it.

I'm okay with the code, but it might be handy to comment this, and/or change the error message to something like:

    "Can't query log position for file %s".

(or, you could SEEK_END instead, and drop O_APPEND from the file open flags; might be a bit more obvious about what you're doing).
Done
I think these two lines should be swapped so that `warn()` prints the error message from `lseek()` instead of `close()`.
Done

LGTM
I tested it and it works fine.
Seems okay, though I'd like one of the other maintainers to +1
I'm ok with not switching the file and/or truncating it for a simple restart of the daemon, but it seems like the change to `log_trim` is not entirely appropriate.
Done

Not obvious to me why you switched from O_TRUNC to O_APPEND since line 60 has a rename of the old file, so we should always end up creating, right?

The function is `log_trim` so if the rename fails, we want to truncate so we don't overflow the max size of the log, correct?
ah, yes.I didn't realize it had to be truncated here
Done
@Andrew could give +2？
small bug with the inttial size setting, but looks good otherwise.
If you've done the `log_trim()`, this will be incorrect. You probably want to set this before the maxsize check, and log_trim will overwrite if necessary.
Done
Done
